channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Macapá Journal: ‘There’s No Law on the Amazon’: River Pirates Terrorize Ships by Night
item.media:description: An Aerial Tactical Group soldier patrolling a canal near the Port of Santana in Brazil.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: As the population surges and drug gangs expand, hijacking opportunities along the Amazon have flourished, and police forces are struggling to keep up.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Protests Erupt in Peru Ahead of Asia-Pacific Economic Meeting
item.media:description: The police in Lima, the Peruvian capital, stood guard during a protest against President Obama on Friday.
item.description: President Obama will attend the gathering, which has led to a wave of demonstrations by Peruvians hoping the international spotlight will help their causes.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE

item.title: Donald Trump, After Fits and Starts, Focuses on Foreign Policy
item.media:description: Members of the news media crowded the lobby of Trump Tower in New York on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect met with the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, and also held meetings with several experts and the Israeli ambassador.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: U.S., in Shift, Backs Arms Embargo for South Sudan as Genocide Risk Rises
item.description: The American ambassador to the United Nations signaled the change of position to help stop the violence convulsing the world’s youngest country.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Myanmar Urged by U.N. Expert to Let Aid Flow to Mainly Muslim State
item.media:description: Ethnic Rakhine men attended a police training course this week in the north of the mainly Muslim state of Rakhine in Myanmar.
item.description: The expert monitoring events in the country also said the government should investigate allegations of abuse instead of brushing them aside with blanket denials.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Ferdinand Marcos Is Buried in Philippine National Cemetery
item.media:description: Police officers barricaded the entrance to the national cemetery on Friday during the burial of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos.
item.description: Activists were stunned that Mr. Marcos, a dictator blamed for thousands of deaths, was being interred in the country’s equivalent of Arlington National Cemetery.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: India Offers Some Relief to Chaos It Created With Currency Ban
item.media:description: Men waited to exchange currency at a bank in Amritsar, India, on Thursday. Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced on Nov. 8 that India’s highest-value bills, the 1,000 and 500 rupee notes, worth about $15 and $7.50, would cease being legal tender.
item.description: The government took steps Thursday to temper growing impatience with the seemingly slapdash way a ban on high-currency bills was carried out.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Obama and E.U. Leaders Agree to Keep Sanctions on Russia
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany greeted President Obama as he arrived for meetings in Berlin with several European leaders on Friday.
item.description: The leaders said that sanctions should stay until Moscow upheld its pledge for a cease-fire and to withdraw of heavy weapons from eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: The Aging Fighter Who May Be Russia’s Favorite American
item.media:description: Jeff Monson at a mixed martial arts tournament last month in Sukhumi, the capital of the Georgian breakaway region Abkhazia. Although he is American, his views have helped make him popular in Russia and pro-Russian enclaves like Abkhazia.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Jeff Monson, a mixed martial arts fighter known as “The Snowman,” is admired for his tenacity and his belief that Moscow is right about most things.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: In Estonia, Caution but Surprising Cheers for Trump’s Victory
item.media:description: The Narva River separates the Estonian town of the same name, left, and the Russian town of Ivangorod. The complex reaction in Estonia to Donald J. Trump’s election victory reflects complicated ethnic, cultural and political factors.
item.description: Leaders in the country’s capital may be terrified, but on the Russian border people hope Donald J. Trump can lower tensions between Washington and Moscow.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Memo from Jerusalem: An Embassy in Jerusalem? Trump Promises, but So Did Predecessors
item.media:description: A poster of Donald J. Trump in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish neighborhood Mea Shearim in Jerusalem. The president-elect has promised to relocate the American Embassy to Jerusalem early in his administration.
item.description: Candidates have long promised to move the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem, only to change course after being elected. Now Israel is waiting to see what President-elect Trump will do.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Iraqis Welcome Trump’s Stance on ISIS, but Fear It May Backfire
item.media:description: Iraqi forces watched television coverage of President-elect Donald J. Trump in the village of Arbid on the southern outskirts of Mosul last week.
item.description: There is hope among Muslims that Donald J. Trump will be more forceful in combating extremists, but also fear that his efforts will be turned against him.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO, FALIH HASSAN and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Silenced for Decades, ‘Victims of Despotism’ Air Torture Claims in Tunisia
item.media:description: Mothers of torture victims carried their sons’ portraits before the Truth and Dignity Commission hearings in Tunis on Thursday.
item.description: In long-awaited public hearings, victims and their families recounted abuses from nearly 60 years of dictatorship, including death and persecution.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: What in the World: Tools to Help Japanese Schoolchildren Find Balance: Unicycles
item.media:description: Most elementary schools across the country offer unicycles for students. At Kyuden Elementary School in Tokyo, an after-school club makes sure the unicycles are neatly hung on their racks and that their tires are full of air.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Most elementary schools across the country offer racks of unicycles on their playgrounds, and many students learn informally from one another, sans helmets.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Sixto Durán Ballén, Former President of Ecuador, Dies at 95
item.media:description: Mr. Durán Ballén was president during a clash with Peru.
item.description: Mr. Durán Ballén led Ecuador in a monthlong border conflict with Peru in 1995, the last war in the Americas to date between sovereign states.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Nepal Releases 41 Tibetans Detained While on Pilgrimage
item.description: The Tibetans were detained by the police while they were on a bus bound for India, and their situation remains “very precarious,” said an advocate for Tibetan rights.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Canada Today: Gay Curlers, Fracking Studies and a Payroll Nightmare
item.media:description: A Pacific Rim Curling League match in Vancouver, British Columbia, in October. Gay curling leagues have blossomed in recent decades, highlighting a distinctly Canadian aspect of modern gay life.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Thousands of Canada’s public servants continue to be shorted on their pay because of persistent flaws in the government’s new payroll system.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Trilobites: Who First Farmed Potatoes? Archaeologists in Andes Find New Evidence
item.media:description: Varieties of potatoes in a restaurant in Lima, Peru. Researchers say the potato may have first been farmed in the Titicaca Basin, which stretches across the boundary of Peru and Bolivia.
item.description: Archaeologists have found ancient starch grains pinpointing the Titicaca Basin of southern Peru as a hearth of early potato cultivation.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: Buckingham Palace, With Its 775 Rooms, Will Be Renovated
item.media:description: Buckingham Palace will be renovated beginning in April. The work is expected to take a decade to complete at a cost of $456 million.
item.description: Britain will spend $456 million on the project, which is expected to take 10 years to alleviate “a serious risk of fire, flood and damage.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Last Wish of Dying Girl, 14, to Be Frozen, Is Granted by Judge
item.description: “I want to have this chance,” the British teenager told the judge after her parents disagreed about the cryogenic preservation procedure.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: NATO Chief ‘Absolutely Confident’ Donald Trump Will Maintain U.S. Role
item.media:description: The secretary general of NATO, Jens Stoltenberg, in Brussels, on Friday, where he said that he looked forward to meeting President-elect Donald J. Trump soon, and that he was certain Mr. Trump would not waver on the United States’ commitment to the alliance.
item.description: Jens Stoltenberg, the alliance’s secretary general, agreed with Mr. Trump that Europe should pay more of the cost of defending itself.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Hero’s Burial for Ferdinand Marcos Draws Protests From Dictator’s Victims
item.media:description: Members of the Marcos family, including the former first lady Imelda Marcos, in black, took part in the funeral procession at the heroes’ cemetery in Manila.
item.media:credit: Office of Governor Imee Marcos, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The interment in a cemetery for Philippine heroes was supported by President Rodrigo Duterte, whose ruthless tactics have been compared to Mr. Marcos’s.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Trump Prepares for His Close-up
item.media:description: Some Chinese have forged successful careers as impersonators of world figures. Among them are Xiao Jiguo, as President Obama, and Jia Yongtang, as the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, relaxing together on a Beijing film set last year.
item.description: Finding products branded with the Trump name is easy in China. Finding someone who can impersonate President-elect Donald J. Trump is not.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Fuel Truck Explosion Kills at Least 73 in Mozambique
item.description: Villagers in a remote part of the African country had been trying to siphon fuel from the vehicle when it was struck by lightning.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: An Unlikely Contender Rises in France as the Antithesis of Trump
item.media:description: Alain Juppé , mayor of Bordeaux, at a campaign rally in Paris on Monday. Mr. Juppé’s soothing message of French unity has, so far, helped him to lead opinion polls.
item.description: Alain Juppé, a former unpopular prime minister who was once convicted of corruption, is now seen by supporters as a measured answer to the resurgent far right.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Sinosphere: Trump Has Called Climate Change a Chinese Hoax. Beijing Says It Is Anything But.
item.media:description: Tangshan, China’s leading steel manufacturing city, has some of the dirtiest air in the country, a challenge to efforts to curb climate change.
item.description: At a conference in Morocco, a Chinese vice minister pointed out that the administrations of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush supported climate change negotiations.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Taiwan May Be First in Asia to Legalize Same-Sex Marriage
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex marriage demonstrated in Taipei, the capital, on Sunday. President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan has spoken out in favor of same-sex marriage.
item.description: A number of bills moving through the legislature and widespread public support could make same-sex marriages legal by early next year.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: As Trump Nears Office, Australian Deal to Move Refugees to U.S. Is in Doubt
item.media:description: Protesters in Sydney, Australia, this month demanding humane treatment of asylum seekers and refugees.
item.description: The deal to resettle refugees and asylum seekers held in detention camps in the Pacific might not happen now that Donald J. Trump is the president-elect.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Obama, With Angela Merkel in Berlin, Assails Spread of Fake News
item.description: President Obama, appearing with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, also warned Donald J. Trump to take the presidency seriously.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Trilobites: Drilling Into the Chicxulub Crater, Ground Zero of the Dinosaur Extinction
item.media:description: An artist’s impression of what the Chicxulub crater might have looked like soon after an asteroid struck the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico. Researchers studied the peak rings, or circular hills, inside the crater.
item.description: By studying hills that formed after an asteroid struck the Yucatán Peninsula, researchers found that materials deep in Earth’s crust were brought toward the surface.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: In Canada, a Direct Link Between Fracking and Earthquakes
item.media:description: A site of hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, in Fox Creek, Alberta. A spate of earthquakes in Alberta within the past five years has been linked to fracking.
item.description: Most fracking-induced quakes in the United States are related to wastewater disposal from oil and gas wells. Scientists see a different culprit in Alberta.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Protest of U.S. Terror Listing Offers a Glimpse at Qaeda Strategy
item.media:description: Nusra Front fighters in Idlib Province, Syria, in 2015. In what analysts say is a calculated move to hide ties to Al Qaeda, the Nusra Front recently changed its name to the Levant Conquest Front.
item.description: Al Qaeda’s Syria affiliate has rebranded, claiming it’s not a threat. And a cleric accused of being in the group’s inner circle insists he’s “independent.”
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Apútzio de Juárez Journal: Avocados Imperil Monarch Butterflies’ Winter Home in Mexico
item.media:description: Davíd Romero Hernández, 51, center, trimming grass in his new avocado orchard on the edge of Apútzio de Juárez, in Mexico, in October.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Spurred by rising demand for the fruit, farmers in the Mexican state that hosts the annual butterfly migration are replacing a vital forest habitat with orchards.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Review: An Anti-Nazi Protest in the Guise of Opera
item.media:description: “Simplicius Simplicissimus” was written in the mid-1930s, but not performed until after the Third Reich had been defeated.
item.description: “Simplicius Simplicissimus,” a little-known work by Karl Hartmann, has a belated British premiere.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WHITE

item.title: Sérgio Cabral, Ex-Governor of Rio de Janeiro, Arrested on Corruption Charges
item.media:description: Sérgio Cabral, center, in Rio de Janeiro in 2014, when he was the state’s governor, and former President Dilma Rousseff, right.
item.description: Mr. Cabral is the latest politician to be implicated in a major graft investigation that has shaken Brazil’s establishment.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Sinosphere: With Fertility Rate in China Low, Some Press to Legalize Births Outside Marriage
item.media:description: A family in Beijing in October. The average Chinese woman will have just 1.05 children, according to recently released findings from a government census.
item.description: The average Chinese woman has just 1.05 children, according to recently released findings from a government census.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Turkey’s Free Press Withers as Erdogan Jails 120 Journalists
item.media:description: Several journalists working for Cumhuriyet, Turkey’s last major independent publication, have been jailed after the July coup attempt. Turkey has surpassed China as the world’s biggest jailer of journalists.
item.description: The journalists have been jailed since a failed coup in July, and news outlets have been closed or taken over by supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Protests at Elite University Show How Egyptian Cash Crisis Tests All
item.media:description: Students protesting at the American University of Cairo on Wednesday, demanding a cap on tuition.
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.description: Students at American University of Cairo are seeking a cap on tuition, reflecting concerns the middle and upper classes have about a flailing economy.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: A New Payroll System Misfires, and Canadians Ask: Where’s My Pay?
item.media:description: Bill Ryan, a leading seaman with the Canadian Coast Guard, stopped receiving any pay in August and told his wife to put off buying back-to-school clothes and supplies for their children.
item.media:credit: Dave Chan for The New York Times
item.description: More than 80,000 public servants have had trouble getting paid because of a system’s flaws, and some managers have even had to lend money to subordinates.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: What in the World: Divorce, India Style: It’s All Up to the Judge
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photo by India Picture/Shutterstock
item.description: How can a wife be cruel to her husband? It’s entirely up to a judge’s discretion to decide whether to support claims of cruelty and approve divorces.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Nepal Is Said to Detain 41 Tibetans Traveling to India
item.media:description: Tibetans in Nepal honoring the Dalai Lama’s birthday in July. About 20,000 Tibetans live in the country, many without passports.
item.description: Many Tibetans trying to reach India cross through Nepal, and in recent years more have been detained and sent back to their Chinese-ruled homeland.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: ‘Is It Safe?’ Foreign Students Consider College in Donald Trump’s U.S.
item.media:description: Naina Lavakare, a senior at the British School in New Delhi, at home on Wednesday. She is concerned about Donald J. Trump’s anti-immigrant messages, her mother said.
item.media:credit: Vivek Singh for The New York Times
item.description: American colleges are worried that the election result could portend a decline in international candidates, and Canadian universities have seen a surge in interest.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and STEPHANIE SAUL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Australia Has a Serious Gambling Problem
item.description: Can anything be done to rein in an industry that sucks millions of dollars out of Australians’ pockets?
item.dc:creator: LIZZIE O’SHEA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Lesson in Emotional Geography
item.media:description: The view from Elias Muhanna’s grandparents’ balcony, in Roumieh, Lebanon, in 2010.
item.description: Thinking about the war in Syria reminds me of my grandmother in the 1980s, who tried to make sense of Lebanon’s scarred landscape from her porch.
item.dc:creator: ELIAS MUHANNA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: How Europe Can Help the U.S., and Defend Itself
item.media:description: U.S. Army soldiers stand in formation during military exercises in April with Bulgaria’s army at the Novo Selo military ground in Bulgaria.
item.description: America has a lot of equipment on the Continent. NATO members should lease it.
item.dc:creator: JOCHEN BITTNER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
